text: the english channel is one of the
busiest shipping lanes in the world and
this year thousands of people in small
boats have crossed it to reach the uk
they set off close to calais in northern
france with the destination of kent in
south east england 40 kilometers away
but as we've seen this week this is a
perilous journey on wednesday at least
27 people drown near calais and the
dangers of these crossings have long
been known yet for some the risks are
worth taking these are people getting
into boats in france this week we know
the number of crossings has gone up
sharply over twenty five thousand people
have made this journey so far this year
and the uk government has repeatedly
promised to make this route unviable so
far it's been unable to and some british
mps think france needs to do more
they have money provided from the
british taxpayer they have drones they
have security intelligence and they need
to get the people the french police down
on the beaches to put a stop to these
boats leaving the french shores
natalie elfix referring to a deal signed
in june where the uk pledged to give
france 54 million pounds to help support
efforts to stop the boats and let's be
clear france has stopped hundreds of
them but still lots of others have got
through and all of this is wrapped up in
political tension the times quoted a uk
government source who called the french
approach macron's brexit punishment
strategy and france is equally
unimpressed its interior minister said
recently we're not taking lessons from
the british they must stop using us as a
punching bag for their domestic politics
but for all this the uk and france know
they must work together and wednesday's
tragedy has given that extra urgency
that may mean more patrols on the french
coast but there's another option the uk
wants to pursue boris and i have worked
intensively with every institution with
a responsibility to protect our borders
to deliver operational solutions
including new sea tactics
which we are working to implement to
turn back the boats that's home
secretary pretty patel in october and as
well as the moral and legal arguments
around turning back the boats france
says without its cooperation it's
impossible to do anyway and as far as we
know not a single boat has been turned
around and that's led to this criticism
from the opposition
headline grabbing plans repeatedly from
the home secretary which achieved
nothing are achieving nothing
well since wednesday's tragedy the uk
government's particular focus has been
people smugglers but the task of taking
them on is getting harder
this single uh method of entry is now
deepened and intensified and has become
so profitable for criminals that it's
going to take a phenomenal amount of
effort to shift it and this method of
entry meaning small boats is now seen by
many people as their best chance of
getting to the uk
by track it's more difficult
and
the degree of success may be like
10 percentage but by by the sea maybe
like 70 to 80 percent and as demand for
crossings increases there's an extra
political dimension to this too because
these crossings have become intertwined
with a desire to control the uk's
borders we told the people at the
referendum us brexiteers that we would
take back control it's clear that in
this we have lost control certainly it
is true that the government hasn't
controlled the crossings as it said it
would but more broadly look at net
migration in the uk this is the number
of people arriving in the uk minus the
number of people leaving it fell by 88
last year then there's the number of
people who are granted asylum by the uk
it's lower than germany france or greece
but for the uk government the focus on
what's happening in the channel is part
of humanitarian concern but it's also
about showing control and it's about a
system that in its view isn't working
we fundamentally believe that people
should seek asylum in the first safe
country
should not be making dangerous journeys
across the channel but many people are
making that dangerous journey for a
number of reasons including family ties
and the english is spoken in the uk and
there's perhaps another factor too
nearly everyone who arrives by boat
applies for asylum and most are accepted
and even if they aren't the vast
majority still stay as we learned in
this exchange can you tell us how many
um i'm seekers or how many people
arriving have been returned to any eu
country in the course of the last year
or since january when this year is five
the high chance of staying may be one
reason the uk is a desirable destination
and if those are the pull factors we
mustn't lose sight of why people choose
to leave home in the year to september
2021 the top five countries of origin of
people applying for asylum were iran
eritrea albania iraq and syria now of
course each person's story is different
some may travel for economic reasons but
the percentage of asylum requests that
are granted by the uk suggests the
people making the crossing have good
reason to leave for their safety as my
colleague louis goodall heard in calais
i've come from iran
kurdistan iraq kurdistan yes and why did
you leave what was that yeah
the politician you know they said me
you must leave the this country or it
will kill you
these personal stories are the reason
this situation in the channel is not
easily resolved the reasons for people
seeking a new home in europe are not
going away nor is the need for better
cooperation in europe as france and the
uk except
this is a complicated issue and there is
no simple fix it does mean a herculean
effort and it will be impossible without
close cooperation between all
international partners and agencies
boris johnson has always said that
brexit won't affect close cooperation
with the eu that's being put to the test
because as pretty patel says no one
country can solve this alone and while
there are still people getting into
dinghies risking their lives and heading
into the channel a solution is
desperately needed
